Award.AwardTitle: REVSYS Collaborative Research: Untangling the Passionflower Vines: Phylogeny, Species Diversification, and Character Evolution in Passiflora Subg. Decaloba (Passifloraceae)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Passiflora represents a diverse group of more than 560 species of vines and trees primarily found in Central and South America. These plants are best known as the source of tropical passionfruit, but are also widely cultivated for their beautiful, complex flowers. Passionflowers appear to be a recently-evolved lineage that has experienced rapid species diversification. Many species are poorly understood with regard to morphology, geographical distribution, and conservation status, especially in the largest lineage of passionflowers, subgenus Decaloba, with 235+ species. This study will synthesize modern and traditional approaches to address these problems, using DNA sequence data, scanning electron microscopy, and observation of fresh and preserved specimens. Field work will enable collection of fresh material and documentation of species distributions. This project will yield a revision of all species in Decaloba, and will provide a modern evolutionary framework within which to address questions about the evolution of floral shape, pollination syndromes, floral development, and the biogeographical history of the lineage.

This study will address important biological and evolutionary questions in an especially charismatic group of plants. Undergraduate and graduate students will participate in the research. Undergraduates at Keene State College and Harris-Stowe State University, institutions that primarily enroll underrepresented groups in the sciences, will especially benefit from involvement in this study. Summer workshops at Rancho Santa Ana Botanic Garden will involve students from the local community. Field expeditions will build international collaborations among U.S. scientists and colleagues in Mexico, Central America, and South America. All results of this project will be available through a website hosted by the Missouri Botanical Garden.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Through our research, presentations, and recent publication, we have produced the first comprehensive study of any subgenus in Passiflora.  This is resulting in the compilation of a modern systematic treatment for a lineage of plants in need of revision; there has been a 60% increase in the number of species described in subgenus Decaloba since last revised.  The project has contributed to our understanding of a rapidly radiating lineage in the angiosperms. This project has highlighted the evolution of convergent floral morphologies in response to pollinators. Evolutionary convergence is often documented among unrelated plant families, but subgenus Decaloba is unique because it represents a closely related clade where vertebrate pollination has arisen at least 15 times; we have found marked lability in morphological characters in Passiflora, with multiple transitions to and from characters present at almost all taxonomic levels examined.  The identification of covarying morphological features related to pollination syndrome is highly relevant to other systematists using floral morphology in their phylogenetic analyses, as these characters may also covary in other unrelated species. Our field studies have provided the first insights into the natural history of never before studied species and through this project we have discovered more than a dozen as yet undescribed species. In addition, the distribution of subgenus Decaloba is similar to several other plant groups and our analyses support a New World origin for Passiflora, with two independent radiations to the Old World.  The monographic work has resulted in the addition of high quality reproductive material to both dried and liquid preserved collections at herbaria around the world. This will aid the identification of species locally, thus improving their chance for conservation. We also now have more detailed distributional data for all species in subgenus Decaloba, which has allowed us to accurately assess their conservation status.

One of the major activities for which I am responsible for this project is the engagement of undergraduates in research at my college.
